latestVersion.termsOfAccess: restricted until associated article published, est. late 2018

fields.value: Growth and site variables in large plots of three agroforestry species in the Peruvian Amazon

dsDescriptionValue.value: The data set consists annualized mean monthly increments in large measurements plots of each of the three species, together with the site (environmental) data for each plot. Each plot consisted of two trees of each of 200 open-pollinated families of each species (established as part of a randomized complete block progeny test). All plots are located in Ucayali region, Peruvian Amazon.

fields.value:
. The variables, where not self-explanatory, are described below:
Identification variables
Case number: Sorting variable
Farmer ID: coded identifier of owner of the land when the block was planted. ICRAF holds the name of each of these individuals.
Zone: locality where planted, as follows:
NR: Nueva Requena
CURI: Curiman√°
SA: San Alejandro
CFB: Carretera Federico Basadre
TOUR: Tournavista
Plot: Number of the plot, nested within each species (i.e. number are non-unique)
Bolaina: indicator variable for species. 1=Guazuma crinita, 0=not Guazuma crinita
Capirona: indicator variable for species. 1=Calycophyllum spruceanum, 0=not Calycophyllum spruceanum
Pijuayo: indicator variable for species. 1= Bactris gasipaes, 0=not Bactris gasipaes

Growth variables
Annualized diameter increment: Basal diameter of all trees in each block were measured at ages between 12-14 months (Guazuma crinita), 15-17 months (Calycophyllum spruceanum), and 18 months (Bactris gasipaes). Mean monthly increments were calculated and then, for ease of presentation and comparison, converted these to annual increments (i.e., multiplying by 12); increments were used in order to minimize confounding of block (i.e. site) effects with measurement ages.
Annualized height increment: Height of all trees in each block were measured at ages between 12-14 months (Guazuma crinita), 15-17 months (Calycophyllum spruceanum), and 18 months (Bactris gasipaes). Mean monthly increments were calculated and then, for ease of presentation and comparison, converted these to annual increments (i.e., multiplying by 12); increments were used in order to minimize confounding of block (i.e. site) effects with measurement ages.

Site variables
Soil samples were collected at 0-15cm during the establishment of each plot.
pH: soil pH in 1:1 soil:water suspension
P: available P (modified Olsen method)
K: Available K
Ca: Exchangeable Ca2+
Mg2+: Exchangeable Mg2+ (ammonium acetate, quantification by atomic absorbtion); CEC: cation exchange capacity (ammonium acetate saturation method, pH7.0)
Al Sat: Al3+ saturation (Yuan method, extraction with KCl, N)
Organic matter: % (oxidation with potassium dichromate)
Proportions of sand, silt, and clay: hydrometer method).
FALLOW: indicator variable for previous land use (1=bush fallow, 0=not bush fallow)
AGRICULTURE: indicator variable for previous land use (1= agriculture, i.e. cultivation of maize or rice, 0=not agriculture)
PASTURE: indicator variable for previous land use (1= pastureland, 0=not pastureland)
Land use was categorized based on direct observations and conversations with the landowners at time of establishment.
